case_name: Messrs. Swadesamitran Ltd., Madras v. their workmen

facts.text: Appeal by special leave arises from industrial dispute between Swadesamitran Ltd. (appellant) and their workmen (respondents).

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, J. This appeal by special leave arises from an industrial dispute between Messrs. Swadesamitran Ltd., Madras  hereinafter called the appellant  and their workmen  h

facts.text: On November 3, 1951, three items of dispute referred to Industrial Tribunal at Madras by Madras Government under s. 10(1)(c) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: ereinafter called the respondents . On November 3, 1951, three items of dispute were referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal at Madras by the Madras Government under s. 10 1  c  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  Act XIV of 1947   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: One item of dispute: whether retrenchment of 39 workmen by appellant in May 1951 was justified, and if not, relief for retrenched workmen.

anchor.surface_text: One of these items was whether the retrenchment of 39 workmen effected by the appellant in May 1951 was justified, and if number, what relief the retrenched workmen were entitled to.

facts.text: On August 26, 1950, respondents addressed charter of 11 demands to appellant, threatening strike if not granted.

anchor.surface_text: It would be relevant to mention briefly the material facts leading to this dispute. It appears that on August 26, 1950, the respondents addressed a charter of demands to the appellant in which eleven demands were made, and they intimated to the appellant that, if the said demands were number granted, they would go on strike.

facts.text: Appellant informed respondents it was working at a loss, retrenchment and rationalisation under consideration, promised sympathetic consideration when finances improve; demands withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pointed out to the respondents that it was working at a loss and that proposals for retrenchment and rationalisation were then under its active companysideration. It promised the respondents that as soon as its financial companydition improved their demands would be sympathetically companysidered. Thereupon the demands were withdrawn

facts.text: On January 24, 1951, respondents sent communication with 13 demands and strike threat to appellant; copy to State Government requesting reference to tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: but on January 24, 1951, another companymunication was addressed by the respondents making as many as thirteen demands companypled with the same threat that if the said demands were number granted the respondents would go on strike. A companyy of this companymunication was sent to the State Government which was requested to refer the said demands for adjudication to the industrial tribunal.

facts.text: Government referred to Conciliation Officer who reported on February 22, 1951 that demands not justified.

anchor.surface_text: The Government, however referred the matter to the Conciliation Officer who found that the demands were number justified. He accordingly made a report on February 22, 1951.

facts.text: On April 24, 1951, Government ordered no case for reference.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately thereafter the respondents wrote to the Government repeating their request for reference, but on April 24, 1951, the Government ordered that numbercase for reference had been made.

facts.text: Appellant effecting retrenchment due to steep rise in newsprint prices, scarcity, Government of India price-page schedule, mechanisation by linotype machines.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile the appellant was taking steps to effect retrenchment in the staff owing to the steep rise in the prices of newsprint and scarcity of supplies, the imposition by the Government of India of a price-page schedule and the progressive introduction of mechanisation in the companyposing section by installation of lino-type machines.

facts.text: Respondents' Union called strike ballot upon learning of retrenchment, decided to strike, issued notice on May 9, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: When the respondents came to know about this their Union called for a strike ballot and as a result of the ballot the respondents decided to go on strike. A numberice in that behalf was issued on May 9, 1951.

facts.text: Strike commenced on May 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Nevertheless the respondents went on strike on May 30, 1951.

facts.text: Services of 39 staff terminated by notice as retrenchment effective May 18, 1951, before strike.

anchor.surface_text: Before the respondents thus went on strike services of 39 members of the staff had been terminated by a numberice as a measure of retrenchment with effect from May 18, 1951.

facts.text: Retrenchment of these 39 workmen is the industrial dispute in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It is the retrenchment of these 39 workmen which led to the industrial dispute with which we are companycerned in the present appeal.

facts.text: Respondents filed writ petition in Madras High Court for reference under s.10(1)(c); allowed, but on appeal modified to direction under s.12(5).

anchor.surface_text: Before this dispute was thus referred for adjudication the respondents had filed a writ petition in the Madras High Court asking for a writ calling upon the Government to make a reference under s. 10 1  c  of the Act. This writ application was allowed but on appeal the Court of Appeal modified the order issued by the original companyrt by substituting a direction that the Government should discharge its duties under s. 12 5  of the Act.

facts.text: On June 12, 1951, strike called off by respondents, offered to resume work; appellant had engaged new hands, re-engaged only some.

anchor.surface_text: On June 12, 1951, the strike was called off by the respondents and they offered to resume work but by then the appellant had engaged new hands and so it was able to re-engage only some of the respondents who offered to resume work.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held strike unjustified, retrenchment of 39 justified though last come first go not strictly followed but justified by preference to mechanically inclined with good eyesight; no unfair practice; no relief.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held that the strike declared by the respondents was number justified and that the appellant was justified in retrenching 39 workmen in question. According to the tribunal, though in retrenching 39 workmen the principle of last companye first go was number strictly followed, the appellant was justified in departing from the said principle because it was entitled to give preference to persons mechanically inclined and having good eyesight. That is why the tribunal rejected the respondents plea that in effecting retrenchment the appellant had indulged in any unfair labour practice. Since the tribunal was satisfied that the retrenchment of 39 workmen was effected in the usual companyrse for good and sufficient reasons it ordered that the said retrenched workmen were number entitled to any relief.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal found tribunal's finding on bona fides and validity of retrenchment not justified; remanded for points including last come first go compliance and unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents challenged this award by an appeal before the Labour Appellate Tribunal. The appellate tribunal was satisfied that the impugned finding about the bona fides and the validity of the retrenchment was number justified. It, therefore, remanded the proceedings to the industrial tribunal for deciding afresh the four points formulated by it. Two of these points are relevant for our purpose. One was whether the formula last companye first go had been companyplied with, and if it was number, the tribunal was asked to scrutinise in relation to each individual whether the reasons for breaking the said rule were sufficient in his case and the other was whether the management was motivated by any unfair labour practice or victimisation.

facts.text: On remand, Industrial Tribunal found necessity for retrenchment justified, no mala fides, but last come first go not observed for 15 of 39; ordered reinstatement of 15 without back wages; no order for 24.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order of remand the industrial tribunal allowed an opportunity to the appellant to lead evidence, and, on companysidering the evidence, it came to the companyclusion that the appellant had made out a case of necessity for retrenchment and that it had justified the extent of retrenchment as pleaded by it. No mala fides in that behalf had been established according to the tribunal. It, however, held that the principle of last companye first go had number been observed in selecting the personnel for retrenchment and it rejected the explanation given by the appellant in retrenching 15 out of the said 39 workmen. That is why it ordered the appellant to reinstate the said 15 workmen without any back wages. In regard to the remaining 24 workmen numberorder was made by the tribunal in respect of any companypensation payable to them.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed necessity for retrenchment of 39, but last come first go not observed, no justification to depart; reinstated 15 with half back wages; 24 awarded half month's wages per year service.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal companysidered these objections and held that the appellant had made out a case for retrenching 39 of its employees but it agreed with the industrial tribunal that the principle of last companye first go had number been observed and that numbercase had been made out to depart from the said principle. That is why it companyfirmed the finding of the tribunal that the 15 named employees should be reinstated and added that they should be given half the amount of their back wages. In regard to the remaining 24 workmen who had been retrenched, the appellate tribunal directed that they should be awarded companypensation at the rate of half a months wages including dearness allowance for each year of service.

facts.text: Present appeal by special leave against Labour Appellate Tribunal's decision.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the present appeal has been preferred by special leave.

facts.text: Both tribunals found strike unjustified and retrenchment of 39 necessary and bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: The first question has been answered in favour of the appellant by both the tribunals below. It has been found that the respondents strike was unjustified and that for the reasons set out by the appellant retrenchment to the extent pleaded by it was also called for and justified.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no inconsistency in finding retrenchment necessary but selection unfair for 15.

anchor.surface_text: It is in regard to this latter aspect of the matter that companycurrent findings have been recorded against the appellant that it acted without justification and the retrenchment of the 15 workmen in question amounts to an unfair labour practice.

facts.text: Industrial rule of retrenchment is last come first go, unless valid reasons to depart.

anchor.surface_text: It may be companyceded that if a case for retrenchment is made out it would numbermally be for the employer to decide which of the employees should be retrenched but there can be numberdoubt that the ordinary industrial rule of retrenchment is last companye first go, and where other things are equal this rule has to be followed by the employer in effecting retrenchment.

facts.text: In 1946, Government of India formulated rules including Rule 4: last engaged first discharged.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1946 the Government of India, in its Department of Labour, formulated certain rules for retrenchment and companymended them to the attention of all employers of labour and trade unions so that disputes on that score may be minimised. Rule 4 amongst the said rules was that as a rule discharge of personnel who are still surplus to requirements should be in accordance with the principles of short service, that is to say, last man engaged should be the first man to be discharged.

facts.text: s.25G of Act statutorily recognizes last person employed first retrenched unless reasons recorded.

anchor.surface_text: We ought to add that the same principle has number been statutorily recognised by s. 25 g  of the Act. This section provides inter alia that where any workman in an industrial establishment, who is a citizen of India, is to be retrenched, the employer shall ordinarily retrench the workman who was the last person to be employed in the same category, unless, for reasons to be recorded, the employer retrenches any other workman

anchor.surface_text: The first point which the learned Attorney-General has raised before us in this appeal on behalf of the appellant is that the Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in law in directing reinstatement when it did not differ from the conclusion of the industrial tribunal that the strike of the respondents was unjustified and that the appellant had acted bona fide in coming to the conclusion that retrenchment of 39 workmen was necessary.

issues.text: whether the Labour Appellate Tribunal has exceeded its jurisdiction in entertaining the grievance of the respondents against their order of retrenchment and inquiring about the validity or reasonableness of retrenchment of certain specified persons

anchor.surface_text: It is then urged that in entertaining the grievance of the respondents against their order of retrenchment the Labour Appellate Tribunal has exceeded its jurisdiction. The case presented before us on this ground assumes that retrenchment is and must be held to be a normal management function and privilege, and as soon as a case for retrenchment had been made out liberty and discretion must be left to the employer to select which employees should in fact be retrenched.

arguments.claim: Precedents on reinstatement despite delay/new hires: Punjab National Bank, National Transport

anchor.surface_text: This companyrt has companysistently held that in the case of wrongful dismissal, discharge or retrenchment, a claim for reinstatement cannot be defeated merely because time has lapsed or that the employer has engaged fresh hands  Vide The Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. The All-India Punjab National Bank Employees Federation and National Transport and General Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen  Civil Appeal No. 312 of 1956 decided on January 22, 1957 .

holdings.text: There is no inconsistency between the findings that the retrenchment of 39 workmen was necessary, justified and bona fide, and the finding that the selection of 15 workmen for retrenchment was unfair and amounted to unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this argument is misconceived. There are two aspects of the question with which the appellate tribunal was concerned in the present proceedings Was the appellant justified in coming to the conclusion in exercise of its management function and authority that 39 workmen had to be retrenched if yes, has the retrenchment been properly carried out ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes between two aspects: (1) necessity/bona fides of retrenchment quantum (accepted), (2) fairness of selection method (rejected for 15); no conflict as separate issues.

holdings.text: Industrial tribunals have jurisdiction to examine the validity and reasonableness of retrenchment selection; retrenchment selection is not an absolute management prerogative but subject to the ordinary industrial rule of 'last come first go' unless justified by valid reasons supported by evidence, with onus on employer.

anchor.surface_text: We are not impressed by this argument. It may be conceded that if a case for retrenchment is made out it would normally be for the employer to decide which of the employees should be retrenched but there can be no doubt that the ordinary industrial rule of retrenchment is last come first go, and where other things are equal this rule has to be followed by the employer in effecting retrenchment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects absolute management discretion; applies industrial rule LCFG (supported by 1946 Govt rules, precedents like Indian Navigation, s.25G statutory recognition); departure requires justification via evidence; interprets J.K. Iron as aligning, not supporting absolute discretion.

holdings.text: The appellant failed to justify departure from 'last come first go' rule for 15 workmen; tribunals' findings that evidence (Lakshminarasimhan testimony, T-1/T-2) was unsatisfactory and reasons demonstrably weak are accepted; such unjustified departure amounts to unfair labour practice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts factual findings of lower tribunals on evidence credibility after remand; no interference in appeal on facts; links to unfair practice via unjustified rule breach.

holdings.text: Improper/illegal retrenchment ordinarily entitles workmen to reinstatement, not defeated by employer's engagement of new hands or litigation delay.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies general remedy rule for wrongful retrenchment; follows precedents (Punjab National Bank, National Transport); discretion of tribunals not to interfere.

holdings.text: Direction for compensation to remaining 24 retrenched workmen at half month's wages per year of service is justified as matter of tribunal discretion.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No substantial challenge; affirms discretion of lower tribunals on relief quantum where retrenchment valid but rule partially breached.

holdings.text: Section 25G of the Industrial Disputes Act statutorily recognizes the 'last come first go' principle, requiring recorded reasons for any departure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.25G imposing statutory obligation aligning with common law industrial rule.

precedents.cited_holding: if the preferential treatment given to juniors ignores the well recognised principles of industrial law of first come last go without any acceptable or sound reasoning a tribunal or an adjudicator will be well justified to hold that the action of the management is not bona fide
